newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine bonds finish up, strong market seen.
newsitem.headline: Argentine bonds finish up, strong market seen.

text.p: Argentine bonds finished much higher Thursday within a market traders say is showing increasing underlying strength which should translate into "We have a positive view -- we continue to recommend peso-denominated bonds," said an analyst at a local brokerage house.
Argentina's FRB Brady bond due 2005 rose 1/2 to 92-1/2, while the dollar-denominated Bocon Previsional 4 due 2002 was $0.35 higher at 115.15.
"The market is very strong," said a trader, recommending buying on market dips ahead of the meeting of the U.S. Federal Open Market Committee May 20.
Players are increasingly thinking the market has already priced in a rate hike at the meeting.

Anyway, said the analyst, if the U.S. yield curve flattens in the case of a U.S. rate hike as she expects, the Argentine market is set to perform well because it is the 30-year U.S. Treasury which has most impact on Argentine bonds.
In the money markets, call money rates rose to 5.98 percent from 5.93 percent.
